Behaviour Displayed : Today, I witnessed a resident asking PSW Erica to take money on their behalf to purchase something for another resident. PSW Erica explained to the resident that, under no circumstances, can staff accept money from residents. Despite this explanation, theresident remained persistent in attempting to give PSW Erica money.At this point, writer intervened and provided further clarification to the resident regarding the policy. I explained that staff are not allowed to accept money from residents under any circumstance, and that this is a measure in place to prevent any misunderstandings.The resident acknowledged the explanation and stated that they understood. I reassured the resident that staff are always available to assist with appropriate services, but that all financial transactions should be handled through the proper channels. Behaviour Displayed : Resident was cooperative and compliant with treatment and routine care provided by this writer earlier in the morning. At that time, the resident allowed care interventions without resistance, and no signs of distress, agitation, or behavioral instabilitywere noted. At approximately 0900 hours, a significant change in behavior was observed. The resident became increasingly agitated and verbally aggressive. She began shouting loudly and repeatedly in the hallway, directing inappropriate, disruptive language toward both staff and fellow residents. This behaviour created a disturbance. Writer approached the resident multiple times in a calm and therapeutic manner in an effort to perform a dressing change on the resident’s left shin, as per medical orders. During each approach, the resident refused care and became escalatingly hostile, both verbally and physically. She used obscene language, raised her voice, and began swinging her arms and legs, making deliberate attempts to strike the writer. While no physical contact occurred, the behavior presented a risk of physical harm to staff and further demonstrated the resident’s inability to safely participate in care at that time. Due to the escalation in behavior, the writer attempted to administerPRN Quetiapine Fumarate 25 mg (oral tablet) as ordered for agitation. the resident refused the medication, continued to display aggressive behavior, and would not engage in de-escalation techniques. Intervention : Time, Frequency and # of Staff : Evaluation of Intervention : Resident Response : ________________

Behaviour Displayed : BSO team received EBSO follow up report recommendations are as follows: 1. Continue with current non-pharmacological approaches/ strategies that are effective in supporting this resident. 2. Recommend closely monitoring resident’s bilateral lower legs for worsening condition/ any signs of infection. Notify the NP/physician for significant findings. 3. Continue considering pain as a trigger for resident’s irritability, restlessness, physical and verbal expressions and refusal during care. Using PAINAD has been helpful, address accordingly. 4. The resident was recently started with scheduled analgesics QID. Continue administration as ordered and monitor effectiveness, if not effective in managing resident’s discomfort, notify NP/physician for consideration of stronger pain medications. 5. The resident was also started on Escitalopram in response to high depression score from most recent Cornell assessment. Recommend monitoring and documenting resident’s response and completing another Cornell Scale for Depression in 4 to 6 weeks from initiation of Escitalopram (approximately between October 14 to 28, 2025) and compare quantitative data from recent assessment to help with evaluation of effectiveness. Despite this intervention, the resident suddenly struck a staff member in the face.Following the review, the BSO team recommends that, in future situations of escalating distress, the resident be gently redirected toa quieter area to help promote a sense of calm and reduce the risk of further agitation. Continued use of GPA strategies is also advised, including validation, maintaining a calm presence, and offering ongoing reassurance to support the resident’s emotional well-being.BSO will continue to monitor. Behaviour Displayed : Intervention : Internal BSO team received External BSO follow up report recommendations are as follows: 1. Review of bowel movements in the last 14 days ending August 29 revealed that the resident continues to have irregular bowel pattern. She had only moved her bowels on 5 out of 14 days. Prune juice has been added by the RD to address constipation on August 8 and Lactulose 15 ml PO BID has also been ordered by the physician on August 12, 2025. Recommend continuing to monitor bowel pattern and notify the NP/physician if bowel pattern continues to be an issue so it can be addressed accordingly. Continue to encourage fluid intake to aid with bowel regularity. 2. The resident continues to exhibit signs of pain, PAINAD scores revealed that resident is experiencing mild to moderate pain. PRN Tylenol has been used 7x since last follow up and all were marked effective. Administration time are between 1430 to 2100. The resident had also complained of pain to her feet and continues to have leg edema. A. Recommend to review recent PRN usage with NP/physician to determine if the resident would benefit from around the clock pain management for optimal pain control. (E.g. Acetaminophen 1200 and 1700) Fluctuating pain levels can lead to stress, anxiety, irritability, and increased focus on pain, which may worsen the perception of discomfort and trigger personal expressions. B. Continue to actively monitor the resident for pain using the PAINAD tool and utilize available PRN Analgesics as needed. 3. The resident continues to exhibit refusal and physical and verbal expressions during care. The BSO Lead Team PSW will collaborate and schedule a supportive observation visit with the IBSO team to identify additional environmental or psychosocial factors contributing to the resident’s expressions during care. The goal is to develop individualized, resident-centered strategies that promote comfort, autonomy, and emotional well-being. 4. Continue to ensure that all team members and especially 1:1 team members supporting the resident have reviewed the resident’s plan of care to ensure they have the appropriate tools prior to supporting the resident. IBSO Team to continue reviewing expectations with 1:1 and reiterating importance of providing resident supervision at ALL TIMES to ensure resident’s and others’ safety. It is also recommended to continue assisting the resident to a quieter environment if possible to reduce overstimulation that has been triggering escalation in expressions. 5. Medication compliance continue to be a concern as per team member report and Page 17 of 19 Summary Effective Date Range: 09/01/2025 to 09/24/2025 Effective Time Range: All Created Date Range: All Created Time Range: All Author: All Department: All Resident Name : Sinadinovski, Radmila (922121005548) Location : 6 420 B Admission 07/18/2025 Date : 9), After-cataract(H26.4), Primary generalized (osteo)arthrosis(M15.0), Benign hypertension(I10.0), Lipid storage disorder, unspecified(E75. 6), Benign neoplasm of meninges, unspecified(D32.9) documentation. Recommend trialing the following strategies to encourage the resident to take her medications: Assess the resident’s mood prior to offeringscheduled medications to determine if timing is best. Offer medications in small amounts and prioritize the most essential medications first. Trial offering medications along with a food/drink of choice. Provide extra time and patience, avoiding pressure. Use stop and go as necessary. The resident’s Brexpiprazole was recently increased to 3 mg OD, it may take some time for the medication to show its therapeutic benefits and effectiveness may also depend on medication compliance. Continue monitoring and documenting resident’s personal expressions and record any changes in intensity and/or frequency. Recommend reviewing in 2-4 weeks and if it is deemed ineffective, consider consulting with NP/physician regarding the possibility of GMHOT involvement for assessment and medication review.
